image.altText: Emergency teams on a foggy road

items.synopsis: Ten people have died and multiple others have been injured in a bus crash in the NSW Hunter Valley, with emergency servicesÂ called to Wine Country Drive at Greta just after 11.30pm on Sunday.

title.children: 10 people die in Hunter Valley crash after bus rolls off roundabout

image.altText: Ambulances attend a scene by the road in the dark.

items.synopsis: The mayor of Cessnock, Jay Suvaal, says the bus came from a wedding earlier on the day and news of the crash was "devastating". Follow live.

title.children: Bus 'appeared to be coming from a wedding', Cessnock mayor says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're hearing that police will be providing an update on the fatal bus crash in about 15 minutes, so stick with us as we bring you the latest as it comes to hand.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Police to provide update on bus crash at 8:45am

children.content: We're hearing that police will be providing an update on the fatal bus crash
, so stick with us as we bring you the latest as it comes to hand.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has sent his condolences to those involved in the fatal bus crash where 10 people died and 11 remained injured. "All Australians waking up to tragic news from the Hunter send our deepest sympathies to the loved ones of those killed in this horrific bus tragedy," Albanese wrote on Twitter. While the cause of the crash is not yet know, Cessnock's mayor said the bus appeared to be returning from a wedding. "For a day of joy to end in such devastating loss is cruel indeed," Albanese added. The prime minister also thanked first responders.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prime minister sends 'deepest sympathies'

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has sent his condolences to those involved in the fatal bus crash where 10 people died and 11 remained injured.
"All Australians waking up to tragic news from the Hunter send our deepest sympathies to the loved ones of those killed in this horrific bus tragedy," Albanese wrote on Twitter.
While the cause of the crash is not yet know, Cessnock's mayor said the bus appeared to be returning from a wedding.
"For a day of joy to end in such devastating loss is cruel indeed," Albanese added.
The prime minister also thanked first responders.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Peta Hughes is a local business owner in Branxton in New South Wales, a town just slightly north of Greta where the fatal bus crash happened. She spoke to News Breakfast earlier and says the roundabout where the bus crashed had been reduced to one lane due to being under construction for "the last couple of months". "The roundabout is under construction at the moment," she said. "So it was a one lane roundabout and they're currently extending and doing road works on it. "They've got barriers and the safety bollards and things up around there. It's a 40km/h zone."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Roundabout reduced to one lane due to construction, local business owner says

children.content: is a local business owner in Branxton in New South Wales, a town just slightly north of Greta where the fatal bus crash happened.
She spoke to News Breakfast earlier and says the roundabout where the bus crashed had been reduced to one lane due to being under construction for "the last couple of months".
"The roundabout is under construction at the moment," she said.
"So it was a one lane roundabout and they're currently extending and doing road works on it.
"They've got barriers and the safety bollards and things up around there. It's a 40km/h zone."
